boat.name: L' Atalanta
boat.full_description:
She was built for the Swedish Customs Service, first named Ran and based at Torekov until 1912. She was said to be too large for Torekov; and Gustaffson built a smaller sister ship, the 27ft Kryess, still a yacht at Malmo.

In 1919 she was converted to the yacht 'Trogen' and owned by a Judge, sold to Bertil Freisler of Malmo and altered to wheel steering and had a 10 hp engine fitted. Converted to Bermudan rig, in 1933 she was sold to Gunnar Malmquist (an Army officer?) to sail round the world and was converted back to a gaff cutter.

She appeared on the British Yacht Register at Cowes, later up on the English East Coast. Owned for 30 years by George Arnott Woodbridge, Suffolk, who cruised as far as the Netherlands, her next owner, Geoffrey Ingram-Smith took her as far as Cherbourg.

L'Atalanta was bought in 1970 at Gt. Yarmouth by Robert Simper of Ramsholt, Suffolk and returned to the River Deben and used for family cruises around the Thames Estuary and for taking part in OGA races rallies and other traditional boat events.
boat.short_description: By 1984, she'd had seven name changes eight owners and four engines, but on inspection after 80 years, all the hull timbers seemed to be 1904, Swedish oak!
